Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Repeat violations require explanation on why the previous corrective action
plan was not successful.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
A staff member at the facility engaged in grooming behaviors with youth to include
inappropriate interactions. Since leaving the facility, youth has been intimately
involved with this staff member.
2

INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Complainant 1 via telephone on January 28, 2021. She reported she
overheard a conversation on January 17, 2021 where Staff 1 and Youth A were
together after Youth A was discharged from Wedgwood. She also reported she was
informed by another person in her home that Youth A and Staff 1 were in an intimate
relationship. However, the person later said they were not being truthful.
I interviewed Youth A via telephone on January 25, 2021 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. Youth A stated he knows Staff 1 as she worked at Wedgwood and
they had a brother/sister like relationship. Youth A denied having any relationship
with Staff 1. Since he left the facility, he has had no contact with her. Youth A
reported his aunt began to make false accusations of him being in a relationship with
Staff 1. He does not know why she did this, only reporting while he was on the
telephone with another girl, his aunt claimed he was talking with Staff 1.
I interviewed the Foster Care Case Manager on January 25, 2021 via telephone. He
reported he was informed by Youth A’s family members that Youth A is in an
intimate relationship with Staff 1. Youth A plans to reside with her and he has spent
time with her since he was discharged from Wedgwood. No specific information was
provided regarding the length of time Staff 1 and Youth A have been in a
relationship.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on January 28, 2021. She denied having an
intimate relationship with Youth A. She denied having any contact with him following
his discharge from Wedgwood.
I interviewed Assistant Supervisor and Therapist at the facility on January 28, 2021
and House Supervisor via telephone on January 28, 2021. They all reported no
knowledge or reports of Staff 1 having an intimate relationship with Youth A, until
these allegations in January 2021.
Assistant Supervisor additionally reported she had multiple conversations with Staff
1 due to boundary concerns but not of a sexual nature. She stated Staff 1 was
assigned a goal worker for Youth A. She had received complaints by other youth
that Staff 1 showed favoritism with Youth A. She also received complaints by staff of
Staff 1 buying items for youth, braiding youth hair, standing by youth’s bedroom
door, and wrestling with Youth A on one occasion. Assistant Supervisor stated that
Youth A was upset on at least two occasions ,crying, as Staff 1 was not working and
he wanted to talk with her. In the Fall, Assistant Supervisor changed Youth A’s goal
worker due to the continued boundary concerns.
Assistant supervisor provided three supervision notes dated 2/24/20, 5/5/20 and
1/7/21 with Staff 1 where they discussed boundaries concerns that included braiding
youth hair, giving gifts to youth, wrestling with youth, and alleged dating of Staff 1.
3

I reviewed Staff 1’s disciplinary record and she does not have any disciplinary record
since her employment in November 2017. I reviewed Staff 1’s training record. She
participated in multiple trainings that address appropriate boundaries with youth.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position
assigned.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance as there is no information to
support Youth A and Staff 1 were in an intimate relationship
while he resided at Wedgwood.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance regarding
supervision and documentation. During Assistant Supervisor’s
interview, she reported she had concerns and many
conversations with Staff 1 regarding her boundaries. There
were three conversation within a year documented in
supervision notes. Assistant Supervisor changed Youth A’s
goal worker from Staff 1 due to these concerns. Even following
the conversations, Staff 1 continued to engage in concerning
behaviors, specifically gift giving. There were no disciplinary
reports on file for Staff 1. When boundary issues are present,
consistent supervision should be provided, documented and
discussed to prevent further issues. If staff are not changing
their behavior, disciplinary action should be sought.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
A staff member in providing gifts to a youth.
INVESTIGATION:
During interviews with Staff 1, Assistant Supervisor, House Supervisor, Therapist,
Youth A and Youth B (who was interviewed at the facility on January 28, 2021), they
all reported staff give youth gifts. These gifts have included cards, gift cards, pens,
clothes, holiday bags and Nintendo switch. Staff reported conflicting information
regarding the gift giving practice. Gifts can be given if you are giving all the youth the
same gift, if the gift is not too excessive, or if you are their goal worker.
4

I reviewed Wedgwood Professional Staff Relationships Procedure. This policy
prohibits staff from spending their own money on youth with rare exceptions allowed
on special occasions, and only with prior approval from clinician and home
supervisor.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as staff are using their
own money to provide a variety of gifts to youth without getting
permission from clinician and home supervisor. Additionally,
staff were unaware of what direction the Wedgwood policy
provides.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
